Chapter 6: The Bodhisattva Lion's Roar
The Bodhisattva Lion's Roar said:
World-Honored One!

If all karmas do not necessarily bring about results, if all sentient beings possess buddha-nature and should cultivate the eightfold noble path, then why is it that all sentient beings do not attain this great parinirvÄá¹‡a?
World-Honored One!
If all sentient beings possess buddha-nature, then they should definitely attain supreme, perfect enlightenment. Why is it necessary to cultivate the eightfold noble path?
World-Honored One!
In this sÅ«tra it is said that if a sick person obtains medicine, a nurse, and proper food and drink according to the illness, or if they do not obtain them, they will all be cured.

All sentient beings are also like this. If they encounter Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, buddhas, bodhisattvas, and good and virtuous friends, if they hear the Dharma being taught and cultivate the holy path, or if they do not encounter, hear, or cultivate the path, they will all attain supreme perfect enlightenment.
Why is this?
Because of buddha-nature.
World-Honored One!
It is like the sun and moon, which no one can block from reaching the edge of the Aá¸a mountain;
The waters of the four great rivers do not reach the great ocean;
The icchantikas do not go to hell;
All sentient beings are also like this. No one can block them from reaching supreme perfect enlightenment.
Why is this?
Because of buddha-nature.
World-Honored One!

For this reason, all sentient beings do not need to cultivate the path, because by the power of buddha-nature they should attain supreme perfect enlightenment, not by the power of cultivating the holy path.
World-Honored One!

If icchantikas, those who commit the four grave offenses, and those who commit the five heinous crimes cannot attain supreme perfect enlightenment, they should still cultivate, because by the power of buddha-nature they will definitely attain it, not by attaining it after cultivation.
World-Honored One!
It is like a magnet, even if far from iron, by its power the iron is attracted.
The buddha-nature of sentient beings is also like this.
Therefore, they do not need to diligently cultivate the path.
The Buddha said:
Excellent, excellent!
Good man!
On the banks of the Ganges there are seven kinds of people who, if they want to bathe, fear bandits, or want to pick flowers, will enter the river.
The first person enters the water and sinks.
Why is it so?
Because he is weak and powerless, and has not learned to swim.
The second person sinks when entering the water, but then emerges. After emerging, he sinks again.
Why is it so?
Because his physical strength is great, he can emerge again;
but because he has not learned to swim, he sinks again after emerging.
The third person sinks when entering the water, but then emerges. After emerging, he does not sink again.
Why is it so?
Because he sinks due to his weight, but emerges due to his great strength, and because he has learned to swim, he stays afloat after emerging.
The fourth person sinks when entering the water, but then emerges. After emerging, he stays afloat and observes the four directions.
Why is it so?
Because he sinks due to his weight, emerges due to his great strength, stays afloat due to his swimming skills, but does not know the place of emergence, so he observes the four directions.
The fifth person sinks when entering the water, but then emerges. After emerging, he stays afloat. After staying afloat, he observes the directions. After observing, he moves on.
Why is it so?
Because of fear.
The sixth person, after entering, immediately leaves and stays in the shallows.
Why is it so?
Because he observes the distance of the bandits.
The seventh person, having reached the other shore, climbs a great mountain, is no longer afraid, is free from all bandits, and experiences great joy.
Good man!
The great river of birth and death is also like this, with seven kinds of people.
Fearing the bandits of afflictions, they intend to cross the great river of birth and death, leave the household life, shave their heads, and wear the Dharma robes.

After leaving the household life, they associate with bad friends, follow their teachings, and listen to and accept wrong teachings, which say that the body of sentient beings is the five skandhas, and the five skandhas are called the five great elements. If sentient beings die, they permanently sever the five great elements. Since they sever the five great elements, why is it necessary to cultivate good and evil karma?
Therefore, know that there is no good or evil, and no retribution for good or evil. This is called icchantika.
Icchantika means cutting off the roots of goodness;
Because of cutting off the roots of goodness, one sinks in the river of birth and death and cannot escape.
Why is it so?
Because of the heaviness of evil karma and the lack of the power of faith, like the first person by the Ganges River.
Good son!
There are six causes and conditions for icchantikas to sink in the three evil paths and be unable to escape.
What are the six?

First, because of the rampant evil mind; second, because of not seeing the afterlife; third, because of enjoying afflictions; fourth, because of being far from the roots of goodness; fifth, because of being obstructed by evil karma; sixth, because of associating with evil friends.
There are also five things that cause one to sink in the three evil paths.
What are the five?

First, because of committing misconduct with a monk, second, because of committing misconduct with a nun, third, because of using the Sangha's property at will, fourth, because of committing misconduct with one's mother, and fifth, because of creating disputes within the five parts of the Sangha.
There are also five things that lead to the three evil destinies.
What are the five?

First, always saying there are no good or bad karmic fruits, second, killing sentient beings who have given rise to the aspiration for enlightenment, third, delighting in speaking of the faults of Dharma teachers, fourth, speaking of what is Dharma as non-Dharma and of what is non-Dharma as Dharma, and fifth, listening and accepting [the Dharma] for the sake of finding faults in the Dharma.
There are also three things that lead to the three evil destinies.
What are the three?

First, saying the TathÄgata is impermanent and will be extinguished forever, second, saying the true Dharma is impermanent and changes, and third, saying the Sangha Jewel can be destroyed. Therefore, one will always sink into the three evil destinies.
The second person refers to one who has the intention to cross the great river of birth and death, but due to severing the roots of goodness, they sink and cannot emerge.
What is meant by emerging is to draw close to good friends and thus attain faith.

Faith means believing in giving and the fruits of giving, believing in goodness and the fruits of goodness, believing in evil and the fruits of evil, and believing in the suffering, impermanence, and destruction of birth and death. This is called faith.
Having attained faith, one cultivates pure precepts, upholds and recites, copies and explains, always practices generosity, and skillfully cultivates wisdom.
Due to dull faculties, one again encounters bad friends and is unable to cultivate body, precepts, mind, and wisdom, and listens to and accepts deviant teachings.
Either encountering bad times or dwelling in bad countries, one severs the roots of goodness;
Due to severing the roots of goodness, one always sinks in birth and death, like the second person on the banks of the Ganges.
The third person refers to one who has the intention to cross the great river of birth and death, but due to severing the roots of goodness, they sink in the middle.
Associating with good friends, they are called 'emerging.'
Faith in the TathÄgata as being omniscient, constant, and unchanging, for the sake of sentient beings, expounds the unsurpassed path:
All sentient beings possess buddha-nature;
The TathÄgata is not extinguished, and the Dharma and Saá¹ƒgha are also like this, without destruction;
The icchantikas and others do not cut off this Dharma, and in the end they cannot attain anuttarÄ-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi. They must distance themselves from it, and only then can they attain it.
Due to the mind of faith, they cultivate pure precepts;
Having cultivated pure precepts, they uphold, recite, copy, and explain the twelve divisions of the scriptures, and widely disseminate them for the sake of sentient beings.
They delight in giving and cultivate wisdom. Due to their sharp faculties, they firmly abide in the faith and wisdom, their minds without regression, like the third person on the banks of the Ganges.
The fourth person is one who wishes to cross the great river of birth and death, but because they have severed their wholesome roots, they sink in the middle.
Because they associate with good friends, they attain faith, which is called emerging.
Because they have faith, they uphold, recite, copy, and explain the twelve divisions of the scriptures.
For the sake of sentient beings, they widely disseminate [the Dharma], enjoy giving, and cultivate wisdom.

Because of their sharp faculties, they firmly abide in faith and wisdom, their minds without regression, and contemplate the four directions - the four directions refer to the four fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a - like the fourth person on the bank of the Ganges.
The fifth person is one who wishes to cross the great river of birth and death, but because they have severed their wholesome roots, they sink in the middle.
Because they associate with good friends, they attain faith, which is called emerging.
Because they have faith, they uphold, recite, copy, and explain the twelve divisions of the scriptures.
For the sake of sentient beings, they widely spread and propagated, delighting in giving and cultivating wisdom.
Because of their sharp faculties, they firmly abide in faith and wisdom, their minds without regression.

Without regression, they then advance - advancing refers to pratyekabuddhas - although they can save themselves, they are not able to save sentient beings, this is called going, like the fifth person on the banks of the Ganges.
The sixth person, having the intention to cross the great river of birth and death, due to severing the roots of goodness, sinks in it.
Associating with good friends, they attain faith, and because of attaining faith, it is called emerging.
Because of faith, they uphold, recite, copy, and explain the twelve divisions of the canon.
For the sake of sentient beings, they widely spread and propagated, delighting in giving and cultivating wisdom.
Because of their sharp faculties, they firmly abide in faith and wisdom, their minds without regression.
Having no regression, they then move forward and finally reach shallow water.

Having reached shallow water, they stay and do not go - those who stay and do not go are called bodhisattvas - in order to liberate all sentient beings, they stay to contemplate afflictions, like the sixth person on the banks of the Ganges.
The seventh person, wishing to cross the great river of birth and death, cuts off the roots of goodness and therefore sinks in it.
Associating with good friends, they attain faith, and having attained faith, this is called emerging.
Because of faith, they uphold, recite, copy, and explain the twelve divisions of the canon.
For the sake of sentient beings, they widely disseminate and spread it, delight in giving, and cultivate wisdom.
Because of their sharp faculties, they firmly abide in faith and wisdom, with minds that do not regress.
Having no regression, they then move forward.
Having advanced and reached the other shore, they ascend a great high mountain, free from all fear, and experience much happiness.
Good man!
The other shore mountain is a metaphor for the TathÄgata;
Experiencing happiness is a metaphor for the Buddha's eternal abiding;
The great high mountain is a metaphor for great parinirvÄá¹‡a.
Good man!
Those people on the banks of the Ganges all have hands and feet but are unable to cross;

All sentient beings are also like this. Although there truly are the Buddha Jewel, Dharma Jewel, and Saá¹ƒgha Jewel, and the TathÄgata always expounds the essential meaning of the teachings and the eightfold noble path, the great parinirvÄá¹‡a, sentient beings are all unable to attain it.
This is not my fault, nor is it a fault of the noble path or sentient beings. One should know that it is all due to the evil of afflictions.
For this reason, all sentient beings are unable to attain nirvÄá¹‡a.
Good man!
It is like a good doctor who knows the illness and prescribes medicine, but the patient does not take it, it is not the fault of the doctor.
Good man!
It is like a donor who gives everything he has to all people, but there are those who do not accept it, it is not the fault of the donor.
Good man!
It is like the sun rising, illuminating all in darkness, but the blind do not see the road, it is not the fault of the sun.
Good man!
It is like the water of the Ganges River that can quench thirst, but the thirsty do not drink it, it is not the fault of the water.
Good man!
It is like the earth universally producing fruits and grains, impartially and without discrimination, but farmers do not plant, it is not the fault of the earth.
Good man!
The TathÄgata universally opens up and explains the twelve divisions of the scriptures for all sentient beings, but sentient beings do not accept them, it is not the fault of the TathÄgata.
Good man!
If one cultivates the path, one will attain supreme, perfect enlightenment.
Good man!
You say:
'All sentient beings possess buddha-nature and should attain supreme perfect enlightenment, just like a magnet.'
This is excellent, excellent! Because of the power of the cause of buddha-nature, one attains supreme perfect enlightenment.
If you say that it is not necessary to cultivate the holy path, this is not so.
Good man!
It is like a person walking through a wilderness, thirsty and exhausted, encountering a well.
Although the well is extremely deep and one cannot see the water, one should know that it must exist.
This person uses skillful means to search for a bucket and rope, and when it is drawn up, one can see it.
Buddha-nature is also like this. Although all sentient beings possess it, they must cultivate the uncontaminated holy path before they can see it.
Good man!
It is like sesame seeds, from which one can obtain oil. Apart from skillful means, one cannot see it;
sugar cane is also like this.
Good man!
Just as the Thirty-three Celestials and the Northern Kurus, although they are existent dharmas, if one lacks good karma, spiritual powers, or the power of the Way, one cannot see them.
The roots of grass in the earth and the water under the earth, because they are covered by the earth, sentient beings cannot see them.
Buddha-nature is also like this. If one does not cultivate the holy path, one cannot see it.
Good man!

As you have said, if a sick person in the world encounters a nurse, a good doctor, good medicine, and food and drink according to the illness, or even if they do not encounter them, they can all be cured. Good man!
I speak this meaning for the bodhisattvas of the sixth stage.
Good man!
It is just like space, which is neither internal nor external to sentient beings. Because it is neither internal nor external, it is also unobstructed;
The Buddha-nature of sentient beings is also like this.
Good man!
It is just like a person whose wealth is in a different place. Although it is not present, they can use it as they wish.
If someone asks about it, they say, I allow it.
Why is this?
Because it definitely exists.
The Buddha-nature of sentient beings is also like this. It is neither this nor that, because it is definitely attainable, it is said to exist in all.
Good man!

It is like sentient beings creating various karmic actions, whether good or evil, which are neither internal nor external. The nature of such karmic actions is neither existent nor non-existent, and it is also not originally non-existent but now existent, not produced without a cause, not created here and experienced here, not created here and experienced there, not created there and experienced there, without creation and without experience. When time and conditions come together, one obtains the fruits of karmic retribution.

The Buddha-nature of sentient beings is also like this. It is also not originally non-existent but now existent. It is neither internal nor external, neither existent nor non-existent, neither this nor that, not coming from elsewhere, not without causes and conditions, and it is also not the case that all sentient beings do not see it.

There are bodhisattvas who see it through the convergence of time and conditions. As for time, it refers to the bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas in the ten abodes who cultivate the eightfold noble path and attain an impartial mind towards all beings. At that time, they see it but it is not called creation.
Good man!
Your statement that it is like a magnet is not correct.
Why is it so?
The stone does not attract the iron.
Why is it so?
Because it has no mental activity.
Good man!
Because different dharmas exist, different dharmas are born;
Because different dharmas do not exist, different dharmas are destroyed. There is no creator and no destroyer.
Good man!
It is just like a raging fire that cannot burn firewood. When the fire comes out and the firewood is destroyed, it is called burning firewood.
Good man!
It is like a sunflower that turns to follow the sun. But this sunflower has no reverent mind, no consciousness, and no activity. Because of the nature of different dharmas, it turns by itself.
Good man!
Just as a banana tree grows when struck by thunder, this tree has no ears, no mind, no consciousness.
Because of the existence of different dharmas, different dharmas grow;
Because of the non-existence of different dharmas, different dharmas perish.
Good man!
Just as when a woman touches an ashoka tree, flowers appear on it.
This tree has no mind, nor does it perceive touch.
Because of the existence of different dharmas, different dharmas arise;
Because of the non-existence of different dharmas, different dharmas perish.
Good man!
Just as when a tangerine tree is fertilized with corpses, its fruit becomes abundant, this tangerine tree has no mind, nor does it perceive.
Because of the existence of different dharmas, different dharmas become abundant;
Because of the non-existence of different dharmas, different dharmas perish.
Good man!

Just as when pomegranate trees are fertilized with bricks, bones, and manure, their fruit becomes abundant, this pomegranate tree has no mind, nor does it perceive.ğŸ”½Because of the existence of different dharmas, different dharmas arise;
Because of the non-existence of different dharmas, different dharmas perish.
Good man!
It is the same with a magnet attracting iron. Because one dharma exists, another dharma is born;
Because one dharma does not exist, another dharma is destroyed.
The Buddha-nature of sentient beings is also like this. It cannot attract unsurpassed, perfect, complete enlightenment.
Good man!

Ignorance cannot attract formations, and formations also cannot attract consciousness, but it can be called ignorance as a condition for formations, and formations as a condition for consciousness. Whether there is a Buddha or not, the Dharma realm is always abiding.
Good man!
If it is said that Buddha-nature abides within sentient beings, good man!
The nature of permanence has no abode. If there is a place of abiding, it is impermanent.
Good man!
The twelve links of dependent arising have no fixed abode. If there were a place of abiding, the twelve links of dependent arising could not be called permanent.
The Dharma body of the TathÄgata also has no abode;
The dharma realm, dharma entrances, dharma aggregates, and space all have no place to abide;
The buddha-nature is also like this, completely without a place to abide.
Good son!

It is like the four great elements, although their power is equal, some are solid, some are hot, some are wet, some are moving, some are heavy, some are light, some are red, some are white, some are yellow, some are black, but these four great elements also have no activity, because they are different from the dharma realm, and each is not similar.
The buddha-nature is also like this, because it is different from the dharma realm, when the time comes it will manifest.
Good son!
Because all sentient beings do not regress from the buddha-nature, it is called having, because of irreversibility.
Because it will exist, because it is certain to be attained, because it is certain to be seen, therefore it is called all sentient beings have the buddha-nature.
Good son!
It is like a king who tells a great minister:
'You lead an elephant and show it to the blind.'
At that time, the great minister, having received the king's order, gathered many blind people and showed them the elephant.
At that time, the blind people each touched it with their hands.
The great minister then returned and said to the king:
'I have already shown it to them.'
At that time, the great king immediately called the blind people and asked them one by one:
'Have you seen the elephant?'
The blind people each said:
'I have already seen it.'
The king said:
'What is the elephant like?'ğŸ”½Those who touched the tusk said the elephant's shape was like a radish;
those who touched the ear said the elephant was like a broom;ğŸ”½those who touched the head said the elephant was like a stone;
those who touched the trunk said the elephant was like a pestle;ğŸ”½those who touched the leg said the elephant was like a wooden mortar;
those who touched the back said the elephant was like a bed;ğŸ”½those who touched the belly said the elephant was like a jar;
those who touched the tail said the elephant was like a rope.
Good man!
It is like the blind people who neither describe the elephant's body nor do not describe it.
If all the characteristics are not the elephant, apart from these there is no other elephant.
Good man!

The king is a metaphor for the TathÄgata, the Worthy One, the Perfectly Enlightened One. The ministers are a metaphor for the Vaipulya MahÄparinirvÄá¹‡a SÅ«tra. The elephant is a metaphor for buddha-nature. The blind are a metaphor for all ignorant beings.
When these beings hear the Buddha's teaching, some say:
'Form is buddha-nature.'
Why is this?
Because although form ceases, it continues in succession, and therefore one attains the thirty-two marks of the unsurpassed TathÄgata. The TathÄgata's form is permanent.
The TathÄgata's form is permanent and unbroken, and therefore form is said to be buddha-nature.
It is like true gold, whose substance may change but its color is always the same.
Sometimes it is made into bracelets, sometimes into snakes, sometimes into bowls, but its yellow color never changes.
The Buddha-nature of sentient beings is also like this. Although the substance is impermanent, the form is permanent. For this reason, form is said to be the Buddha-nature.
Some say:
'Feeling is the Buddha-nature.
Why is it so?
Because of the causes and conditions of feeling, one attains the true bliss of the TathÄgata.
The feeling of the TathÄgata refers to the ultimate feeling of ultimate truth.
Although the nature of feeling of sentient beings is impermanent, it continues in sequence without interruption. For this reason, one attains the permanent feeling of the TathÄgata.
It is like a person whose surname is KÄÅ›yapa. Although the person is impermanent, the surname is permanent, and it does not change for thousands of generations.
The Buddha-nature of sentient beings is also like this. For this reason, feeling is said to be the Buddha-nature.
Some also say:
'Conception is the Buddha-nature.
Why is it so?
Because of the causes and conditions of conception, one attains the true conception of the TathÄgata.
The conception of the TathÄgata is called the conception of no conception.

The thought of no thought is neither the thought of sentient beings nor the thought of male and female, nor the thought of form, feeling, perception, mental formations, or consciousness, nor the thought of annihilation.
Although the thought of sentient beings is impermanent, because the continuity of thought is uninterrupted, one attains the thought of the TathÄgata's permanence and constancy.
Good son!
It is like the twelve links of dependent arising of sentient beings. Although sentient beings cease, the links of dependent arising are constant.
The buddha-nature of sentient beings is also like this. For this reason, thought is said to be the buddha-nature.
There are also those who say:
'Action is the buddha-nature.'
Why is it so?
Action is called life.
Because of the causes and conditions of life, one attains the TathÄgata's eternal life.
Although the life of sentient beings is impermanent, because the continuity of life is uninterrupted, one attains the TathÄgata's true and eternal life.
Good son!
It is like the twelve divisions of the scriptures - although the listeners and expounders are impermanent, the scriptures remain forever unchanged.
The Buddha-nature of sentient beings is also like this, and for this reason, it is said that practice is the Buddha-nature.
There are also those who say:
Consciousness is the Buddha-nature.
Because of the causes and conditions of consciousness, one attains the mind of equality of the TathÄgata.

Although the consciousness and mind of sentient beings are impermanent, because the succession of consciousnesses continues without interruption, one attains the true and permanent mind of the TathÄgata.
Just as the heat of fire is impermanent, but heat is not impermanent.
The Buddha-nature of sentient beings is also like this. For this reason, it is said that consciousness is the Buddha-nature.
There are also those who say:
Apart from the aggregates, there is a self, and this self is the Buddha-nature.
Why is it so?
Because of the causes and conditions of the self, one attains the eight liberations of the TathÄgata.
There are non-Buddhists who say:
'Going, coming, seeing, hearing, sorrow, joy, speaking, and saying are for the self.'
Although the characteristics of the self are impermanent, the self of the TathÄgata is truly permanent.
Good man!
Just as the aggregates, sense bases, and elements are impermanent but their names are permanent, the Buddha-nature of sentient beings is also like this.
Good man!
Just as the blind people each describe the elephant, although they do not get the truth, it is not that they do not describe the elephant.
Those who speak of Buddha-nature are also like this. It is neither the six dharmas nor apart from the six dharmas.
Good man!
Therefore, I say that the Buddha-nature of sentient beings is neither form nor apart from form, up to neither self nor apart from self.
Good man!
Although some non-Buddhists speak of a self, there is actually no self.
The self of sentient beings is precisely the five aggregates. Apart from the aggregates, there is no separate self.
Good man!
It is like a lotus flower consisting of stem, leaves, pistils, and pericarp, apart from which there is no other flower;
The self of sentient beings is also like this.
Good man!
It is like a house consisting of walls, beams, grass, and wood, apart from which there is no other house;
It is like a forest consisting of khadira trees, pÄruá¹£aka trees, nyagrodha trees, and udumbara trees, apart from which there is no other forest;
It is like an army consisting of chariots, elephants, horses, and infantry, apart from which there is no other army;
It is like a brocade consisting of multicolored threads, apart from which there is no other brocade;
It is like a great assembly consisting of the four castes, apart from which there is no other assembly;
The self of sentient beings is also like this, apart from the five aggregates there is no other self.
Good man!
The TathÄgata's permanence is called the self.
The TathÄgata's Dharma body is boundless and unobstructed, unborn and unceasing, attaining the eight liberations, this is called the self.
Sentient beings' true nature lacks this self and what belongs to the self, but because they will definitely attain the ultimate emptiness of ultimate truth, it is called buddha-nature.
Good son!
Great kindness and great compassion are called buddha-nature.
Why is it so?
Great kindness and great compassion always follow the bodhisattva like a shadow follows a form.
All sentient beings will definitely attain great kindness and great compassion, therefore it is said that all sentient beings possess buddha-nature.
Great kindness and great compassion are called buddha-nature;
buddha-nature is called the TathÄgata.
Great joy and great equanimity are called buddha-nature.
Why is it so?
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, if they are unable to abandon the twenty-five existences, then they are unable to attain supreme, perfect enlightenment.
Because all sentient beings will definitely attain it, therefore it is said that all sentient beings possess buddha-nature.
Great joy and great equanimity are precisely buddha-nature, and buddha-nature is precisely the TathÄgata.
Buddha-nature is called the mind of great faith.
Why is it so?
Because of the mind of faith, bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are able to perfect the pÄramitÄ of giving and up to the pÄramitÄ of wisdom.
Because all sentient beings will definitely attain the mind of great faith, therefore it is said that all sentient beings possess buddha-nature.
The mind of great faith is precisely buddha-nature, and buddha-nature is precisely the TathÄgata.
Buddha-nature is called the stage of the only child.
Why is it so?
Because of the causal condition of the stage of the only child, bodhisattvas attain an impartial mind towards all sentient beings.
Because all sentient beings will definitely attain the stage of the only child, therefore it is said that all sentient beings have buddha-nature.
The stage of the only child is precisely buddha-nature, and buddha-nature is precisely the TathÄgata.
Buddha-nature is called the fourth power.
Why is it so?
Because of the fourth power, the bodhisattva is able to teach and transform sentient beings.
Because all sentient beings will definitely attain the fourth power, therefore it is said that all sentient beings have buddha-nature.
The fourth power is precisely buddha-nature, and buddha-nature is precisely the TathÄgata.
Buddha-nature is called the twelve links of dependent arising.
Why is it so?
Because of dependent arising, the TathÄgata abides eternally.
All sentient beings definitely have such twelve links of dependent arising, therefore it is said that all sentient beings have buddha-nature.
The twelve links of dependent arising are precisely buddha-nature, and buddha-nature is precisely the TathÄgata.
Buddha-nature is called the four unobstructed understandings.
Because of the four unobstructed understandings, one speaks without obstruction of words and meanings;
Because of the unobstructed understanding of words and meanings, one is able to transform sentient beings.
The four unobstructed understandings are the buddha-nature, and the buddha-nature is the TathÄgata.
Buddha-nature is called the samÄdhi of the peak.
By cultivating this samÄdhi of the peak, one is able to comprehensively encompass all the teachings of the Buddha. Therefore, it is said that the samÄdhi of the peak is called the buddha-nature.
Bodhisattvas in the ten abodes cultivate this samÄdhi but have not yet perfected it. Although they see the buddha-nature, it is not clear.
Because all sentient beings will definitely attain it, it is said that all sentient beings have the buddha-nature.
Good man!
